title: Observation of As-Quenched DU-6wt%Nb Microstructure by Transmission Kikuchi Diffraction
content: The metastable U-Nb alloys with compositions near 6 wt% Nb have improved corrosion resistance and ductility compared to pure, orthorhombic U [1]. When quenched sufficiently rapidly from its high-temperature γ (bcc) phase, depleted U-6wt%Nb adopts a monoclinic, highly twinned martensite phase known as α’’. Material in this condition is regarded as belonging to the class of high-temperature shape-memory alloys (SMAs), and it can recover up to 7% tensile strain by heating into the γ phase [2]. The as-transformed martensitic microstructure has previously been studied by conventional transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques. Crystal orientation mapping techniques like EBSD have yielded valuable information about the as-transformed microstructures in other SMAs (e.g., [3], [4]). However, the high density of nanoscale twins in as-quenched DU-6wt%Nb has posed challenges for these techniques.
